items.text: To keep it short and sweet: When thewarehouse.co.nz rolled out and intermingled their 'marketplace' listings with products that are locally available, they did implement a filter to remove them, but it reset on each new query
Sooo... Because this was mildly annoying, I wrote a Chrome Extension to fix the behaviour
I was mildly annoyed by the behaviour of the new site
At some point the behaviour was fixed, meaning that this (Manifest V3 btw) extension is no longer necessary

sections.name: Manifest V3 and How It Works?

items.text: It just so happened that I started toying around with this extension right as Google stopped allowing new *Manifest V2* submissions to the Chrome Web Store. So, naturally, I had to go and learn Manifest V3.

Originally, this extension used the chrome.webRequest API to intercept and modify outgoing requests to thewarehouse.co.nz. With webRequest.onBeforeRequest and the blocking permission, I could dynamically tweak the request URL and append query parameters based on user preferences (like filtering out marketplace or online-only products).
But thatâ€™s not allowed anymore in Manifest V3 everything has to be defined up front as declarative rules. No more freeform request tampering at runtime.
So now it uses addOrReplaceParams rules to inject query parameters into requests, which does the same thing, just... a little less dynamically. Yes, I know ... super exciting and complex stuff.
Im kinda running out of things to fill this up with... here's the explicit parameters we add
And these parameters are added only when the URL matches the specified patterns for The Warehouse site, specifically when the URL contains either '/search' or '/c' paths on thewarehouse.co.nz domain.
